review.title: Reordering rules for English-Hindi SMT
review.abstract: Reordering is a preprocessing stage for Statistical Machine Translation (SMT) system where the words of the source sentence are reordered as per the syntax of the target language. We are proposing a rich set of rules for better reordering. The idea is to facilitate the training process by better alignments and parallel phrase extraction for a phrase-based SMT system. Reordering also helps the decoding process and hence improving the machine translation quality. We have observed significant improvements in the translation quality by using our approach over the baseline SMT. We have used BLEU, NIST, multi-reference word error rate, multi-reference position independent error rate for judging the improvements. We have exploited open source SMT toolkit MOSES to develop the system.

metadata.title: Reordering rules for English-Hindi SMT

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This paper describes syntactical reordering rules to reorder English sentences according to the Hindi language structure. Generally, the reordering approach analyzes the source sentence (E ") and applies syntactic reordering rules to form reordered sentences (E.") Training of the SMT system takes place using a parallel corpus, with the source page reordering (E ") and the target page reordering. Source sentences prior to decoding are reordering using the same syntactic rules as those applied to the training data. Thus, this process functions as a preprocessing phase for the phrase-based SMT system. It has been observed that a reordering as a preprocessing phase is beneficial for the development of the English-Hindi phrase-based SMT system (Ra-manathan et al, 2008; Rama et al et al, 2014). This paper describes a rich set of rules for the 2006 De-Hindi structural transformation of the English language structure (using the Hindi sentence).

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: These proposed methods balance the word order differences between the source and target language sentences by reordering the source prior to SMT training and decoding stages. For English-Hindi statistical machine translation, the previous reordering is done by Ramanathan et al. (2008) and Rama et al. (2014). This approach (Ramanathan et al., 2008) has also shown that significant im-ar Xiv: 161 0.07 420v 1 [cs.C L] October 24, 201 6provements over baseline (Brown et al., 1990; Marcu and Wong, 2002; Koehn et al., 2003). With the reordering, the BLEU score for the system has increased from 12.10 to 16.90. The same reordering approach (Ramanathan et al al al al al., 2008) is used by us (with the other test kit), has a slight improvement in the BLEU score from 0.64 above baseline.

sections.heading: 3 Reordering approach
sections.text: Our reordering approach is based on a syntactical transformation of the English sentence tree according to the target language (Hindi) structure. It is similar to Ramanathan et al. (2008), but the transformation rules are not limited to SVO to SOV and pre-modifiers to describe only post-modifying transformations.The idea was to find generic syntactic transformation rules that correspond to the target language grammar structure.The motivation stems from the fact that if words are already in the correct place in relation to other words in the sentence, the system does not need to do the additional work of reordering in the decryption time.This problem becomes even more complicated when the system is unable to obtain larger sentences for the translation of a sentence. If the system is able to obtain only 2-word length sentences, there are 362880 (9!) translations (permutations) that are possible.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments and Results
sections.text: The experiments were performed on the corpus described in Table 2.The baseline system was established using the phrase-based model (Brown et al., 1990; Marcu and Wong, 2002; Koehn et al., 2003).For the language model, we conducted experiments and found in a comparison that the 5 gram model with modified Kneser-Ney smoothing was used (Chen and Goodman, 1996) to achieve the best results.The target Hindi corpus from the training set was used to create the language model.The KenLM (Heafield, 2011) toolkit was used for speech modeling (Chen and Goodman, 1996) to use the weight differences for the language models, the phrase translation model, etc., with minimal error rate training (Och and Ney, 2003).The decoding was performed using the MOSES decoder.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: Until now, we have tried these rules only for English-Hindi pairs, but it is planned to apply similar rules for other English-Indian language pairs, as most Indian languages are structurally similar to Hindi. Furthermore, a comparative study on an improved reordering system and hierarchical models is planned.
